newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Oversupply to prompt shakeout in S.Korea car sector.
newsitem.headline: Oversupply to prompt shakeout in S.Korea car sector.

text.p: A shakeout in South Korea's car industry, the world's fifth largest, looks inevitable as unchecked expansion by domestic car makers leads to oversupply, analysts said.
The capacity of South Korea's three leading automakers -- Hyundai Motor, Kia Motors and Daewoo Motor -- is set to top six million units annually by 2000, up from the current four million.
On top of that, Ssangyong Motor and newcomer Samsung Motors are scheduled to squeeze into the already crowded passenger car market.
"All of them cannot survive. There will be a big shakeout in two or three years," said Nam Seung-soo, an analyst at Daishin Economic Research Institute.
Domestic sales stood at 1.64 million in 1996 and are not expected to increase much this year as the slowing economy slashes spending on durable goods.
But Ssangyong, the Korean partner of Mercedes-Benz, a subsidiary of Daimler-Benz, would begin producing luxury sedans in October with an annual capacity of 50,000 units.
The company, a specialised maker of four wheel-drive utility vehicles, wants to make 200,000 passenger cars in 2000.
Samsung entered into a technical tie-up with Japan's Nissan Motor in 1994 and its first cars -- modified versions of Nissan's Maxima sedans -- are expected to go on sale from March 1998.
Samsung aims to sell 80,000 cars in the first year and hopes to raise production to 500,000 by 2002 and one million by 2010.
"The timing of Ssanyong's expansion and Samsung's entry could not be worse. They will add to oversupply," said Yang Dong-ki, an analyst at Dongbang Peregrine Securities.
"They seem to have some fantasy about the car industry," said Chang Choon-rin, analyst at Daewoo Research Institute.
He said the domestic vehicle market had reached saturation and car makers were too optimistic about overseas sales.
Car producers say they will look more to exports to overcome excessive capacity and slowing sales at home.
But critics said it would not be easy for South Korean companies to make models attractive to foreign customers.
Flaws in Hyundai's Excel compact sedans exported to the United States in the late 1980s badly damaged the reputation of Korean cars.

South Korea's car exports to the United States dropped to 201,470 units in 1996 from a peak of 481,100 in 1988, while total exports rose to 1.2 million units from 576,134, according to the Korea Automobile Manufacturers' Association.
"Falling sales figures in the U.S., the most sophisticaed market, showed the status of Korean makers, known for low-priced and mediocre-quality cars," said Hur Kang, an analyst at Hyundai Securities.
South Korean producers, now suffering from rising inventories, introduced a slew of incentives in April, including non-interest instalment payment schemes, to jack up sales.
Analysts said car makers cut export prices by about five percent in addition to offering higher margins to overseas dealers.
"These schemes helped push up sales but must have hurt profitability," said Sohn Jong-won, an analyst at Ssangyong Investment and Securities.
